intro: Sida ostryifolia, commonly known as the arrowleaf sida, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its soft, hairy leaves and showy flowers. The plant typically grows in wetland or marshy areas, thriving in moist, sandy soils. Its small, five-petaled flowers are usually pink or purple, and it produces capsules containing numerous seeds. Sida ostryifolia is often found in wetlands and is an important plant for supporting local biodiversity.
